website_summaries.verdict: The Fujifilm QX2 doesn't improve much on its predecessor, but with its larger image sensor, bright lens and fast performance even in low light, this stylish pocket camera is an excellent step-up from your smartphone or average point-and-shoot.
pros: The Fujifilm XQ2 is an attractive advanced compact with a fast f1.8 maximum aperture and good low-light photo quality
It has a satisfying mix of manual and automatic shooting options and plenty of things with which to experiment
There's ample direct control over settings given the camera's small size
cons: The XQ2 has limited Wi-Fi functionality
it's essentially the same as its predecessor, the XQ1
and video quality is just OK

customer_reviews.title: Good Sized Sensor in a Tiny Camera
customer_reviews.text: This is a very rare beast, with its 2/3" sensor in such a small camera. It handily outperforms, in terms of image quality, all the other small pocketable cameras on the market. How they got the same sensor used by the much larger Fujifilm X30 into this little body I can't imagine, but it was a stroke of luck to find it. Operations are smooth and fast, and construction is first rate...typical for Fujifilm. Image quality is wonderful. This model is a few years old now, but it's a real gem if you can find one.

customer_reviews.title: Had trouble recording any video -- an empty 64 GB memory card only could record 30 minutes?
customer_reviews.text: Had the camera for about 4 days before returning. We took it on a short trip and tried recording videos with it... with a brand new 64 GB memory card, the camera could only record 30 minutes TOTAL. On top of this the quality was terrible. We ended up switching it in for a Sony RX100 III, which was a lot better in terms of image/video quality and storage capacity.
